page.title: 11Early Travel in Upton.
page.content: {River crossing}was by{ferry,}later a wooden bridge. A stone bridge of six arches came later in the 17th cent. Upton grew and prospered in the mid 16th cent. building timber framed houses with profits from fishing and farming. The quay was used to load and unload goods and produce from surrounding areas and tea from China for{Upton Tea Exchange.}The Severn Trow was used. A swing bridge was built in 1854 after the collapse of the stone one damaged in the Civil War. With no roads existing for many centuries overland transport was by pack horse. {Roman}roads existed from AD43. By the 18th cent. roads were made encouraging stage coach travel with posting inns, the Star and the White Lion. Railways replaced horse transport and the coming of motors closed the railways.
